oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Experimental investigation on an axisymmetric turbulent jet impinging on a concave surface
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: HASHIEHBAF, A
BARAMADE, A
AGRAWAL, A
ROMANO, GP
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: SEMICIRCULAR CONVEX SURFACE
HEAT-TRANSFER
ROUND JET
STOCHASTIC ESTIMATION
CYLINDRICAL SURFACES
AIR-JET
FLOW
IMPINGEMENT
NOZZLE
WALL
Impinging jet
Turbulent axisymmetric jet
Concave surface
Particle image velocimetry
Linear stochastic estimation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An experimental study of an axisymmetric turbulent jet impinging on a semi-cylindrical concave surface is carried out using Particle Image Velocimetry (Ply). The measurements are performed on two orthogonal planes: parallel and perpendicular to the axis of the cylinder. The study is focused on the impinging jet, the generated wall jet and on the boundary layer developing on the cylinder surface. Linear stochastic estimation is applied for identifying the dominant structures in the flow and coupling then with other relevant parameters as the peak r.m.s. velocity of the wall jet to estimate secondary peak in Nusselt number distribution along the wall. Measurements are performed for two different surface curvatures and four nozzle to target distances (Lid ratio) at a Reynolds number equal to Re approximate to 30, 000. The mean and r.m.s. velocity profiles are investigated and the evolution of half-velocity width close to the wall is illustrated for both planes of interest. The results show a strong lateral movement of the flow brought about by the surface geometry for curved surface, especially for large L/d ratios. The r.m.s. profiles indicate higher values along the curved surface with respect to the quasi-flat one. The results show the most probable position of secondary peak in the Nusselt number distribution along quasi-flat and curved surfaces to be located at y/d = 3.2 and 4.39 < s/d < 5, respectively. These results can be used toward interpretation of heat and mass transfer aspects on concave surfaces, and are also useful for benchmarking future numerical studies. (C) 2015 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF HEAT AND FLUID FLOW, 53,167-182
